## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-09-29T12:20:06Z
## Message ID: 20170929-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux is above 10^5 pfu starting at 2017-09-29T08:45Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a high speed stream starting at 2017-09-27T04:06Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2017-09-29T08:45:00-RBE-001.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Geomagnetic Storm
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-09-28T12:59:24Z
## Message ID: 20170928-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Intensified space weather storm in the Earth's magnetosphere. Geomagnetic Kp index reached level 7 (strong) during the synoptic periods 2017-09-28T03:00Z to 2017-09-28T06:00Z and 2017-09-28T06:00Z to 2017-09-28T9:00Z.

The storm was caused by high speed stream starting at 2017-09-27T04:06Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO, polar and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's ring current and auroral regions can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2017-09-27T18:00:00-GST-001.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for September 20, 2017 - September 26, 2017
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-09-27T20:15:53Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2017-09-20T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2017-09-26T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20170927-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There was one C-type CME (see details below).   

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=3 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2017-09-24T21:00Z-24:00Z and 2017-09-25T00:00Z-03:00Z.  This small increase was associated to the arrival of a small coronal hole high speed stream around 2017-09-24.  The solar wind reached values of ~450 km/s on 2017-09-25.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES were elevated and above the threshold of 10^5 pfu at the beginning of the reporting period due to the coronal hole high speed stream that was detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2017-09-14 (see notification 20170921-AL-001 for this reporting period).  The fluxes decreased below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu on 2017-09-22 and remained below the threshold for the remaining time of the reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the significantly elevated energetic electron flux on the Earth's outer radiation belt described above at the beginning of the reporting period.


##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed 

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed 

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2017-09-24T11:36Z     ~675            C               175/41                10                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2017-09-27T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2017-10-03T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low to moderate for the next upcoming period.  There are active regions present on the solar disk that have the potential to produce solar flares and coronal mass ejections.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to be moderate to high for the upcoming week due to the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream that was detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 on 2017-09-27.  Solar wind speeds are currently >650 km/s and the Kp index reached Kp=5 for the synoptic period of 2017-09-27T06:00Z-09:00Z.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for September 13, 2017 - September 19, 2017
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-09-20T22:56:30Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2017-09-13T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2017-09-19T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20170920-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at moderate levels during this reporting period. There were two C-type CMEs and one O-type CME (see details below) originating from former AR 12673. Simulations indicated that the two CMEs starting on 2017-09-17T12:09Z and 2017-09-17T14:24Z would impact STEREO A, and have a flank impact at missions at Mars, Spitzer and the Dawn spacecraft (see notifications 20170917-AL-003, 20170917-AL-004 and 20170918-AL-003). The CMEs were observed to arrive at STEREO A at around 2017-09-19T03:00Z.

Geomagnetic activity was at moderate levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=6 for the reporting period. The Kp index reached level 6 (moderate) during the synoptic periods 2017-09-14T15:00Z to 2017-09-14T018:00Z, 2017-09-15T00:00Z to 2017-09-15T03:00Z and 2017-09-16T03:00Z to 2017-09-16T06:00Z, all due to a high speed stream arriving at Earth midday on 2017-09-14 (see notification 20170914-AL-002).
 
The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 10^5 pfu starting at 2017-09-15T12:55Z and continued to remain elevated through the rest of the reporting period. This was due to the increased solar wind speed starting on 2017-09-14, described above (see notifications 20170915-AL-001, 20170915-AL-002, 20170917-AL-001, 20170917-AL-002, 20170919-AL-001).

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES was at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Two solar energetic particle events were detected by STEREO A on 2017-09-13 and 2017-09-17.  The flux of 13-100 MeV protons exceeded 0.1 pfu/MeV starting at 2017-09-13T05:33Z (after a datagap) associated with the CME starting on 2012-09-10T16:09Z and remained elevated until 2017-09-16  (see previous weekly report 20170914-7D-001and notifications 20170913-AL-002, 20170915-AL-003). Soon after, the flux of 13-100 MeV protons exceeded 0.1 pfu/MeV again starting at 2017-09-17T23:40Z (after a datagap) associated with the CMEs starting on 2017-09-17T12:09Z and 2017-09-17T14:24Z and reached a peak flux of 4.75 pfu/MeV on 2017-09-19 when CMEs arrived at the spacecraft (see simulation discussion above and notification 20170918-AL-002).

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft in the vicinity of STEREO A are expected to be medium to high this week, due to the elevated energetic proton flux. Also, missions near Earth may be impacted by the significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):
Earth directed:
None Observed 

Non-Earth directed:

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2017-09-20T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2017-09-26T23:59Z

The solar and geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week. Former AR 12673 is currently at around -130 degrees longitude and is continuing to produce flares and CMEs and will rotate onto the Earth-facing solar disk within the next three days, and will be near disk center around 2017-09-30. A high speed stream is expected to produce negligible speed increases over the next few days at Earth, but a faster high speed stream is expected around 2017-09-28 that may produce geomagnetic activity.

## Summary:

20170915-AL-002

This is an update to notifications 20170915-AL-002 & 20170917-AL-002

Continued elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux is above 10^5 pfu starting at 2017-09-15T12:55Z and is currently at 167000 pfu.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a high speed stream starting at 2017-09-14T12:00Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2017-09-15T12:55:00-RBE-001.

## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux has been above 10^5 pfu starting at 2017-09-15T12:55Z (see notification ID 20170915-AL-001). The electron fluxes continue to be elevated crossing the threshold again at 2017-09-17T12:25Z.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a high speed stream starting at 2017-09-14T12:00Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2017-09-15T12:55:00-RBE-001.

## Message ID: 20170916-AL-004
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

This is an update to the automatic notification with ID 20170916-AL-001 which was sent on 2017-09-16T04:47Z. This automatic notification was produced in error due to the 13-100 MeV proton flux fluctuating near the threshold of 10^-1 pfu/MeV while decreasing. The 13-100 MeV proton flux is now below the 10^-1 pfu/MeV threshold.

Activity ID: 2017-09-13T05:33:00-SEP-001.

## Notes: 

Although the 13-100 MeV proton flux is now below threshold, this original SEP event (2017-09-13T05:33:00-SEP-001) began at 2017-09-13T05:33Z and was associated with CME with ID 2017-09-10T16:09:00-CME-001 (see notification(s) 20170910-AL-006, 20170910-AL-007, 20170911-AL-001, 20170911-AL-002), C3.0 flare with ID 2017-09-12T07:23:00-FLR-001 which peaked at 2017-09-12T07:29Z, and C1.6 flare with ID 2017-09-12T19:03:00-FLR-001 which peaked at 2017-09-12T19:20Z.

## Summary:

Ongoing space weather storm in the Earth's magnetosphere. Geomagnetic Kp index has reached level 6 (moderate) during the synoptic period 2017-09-16T03:00Z to 2017-09-16T06:00Z. 

The storm is caused by high speed stream starting at 2017-09-14T12:00Z.

## Summary:

Ongoing space weather storm in the Earth's magnetosphere. Geomagnetic Kp index has reached level 6 (moderate) during the synoptic period 2017-09-14T15:00Z to 2017-09-14T18:00Z. 


NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO, polar and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's ring current and auroral regions can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2017-09-14T15:00:00-GST-001.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for September 06, 2017 - September 12, 2017
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-09-14T00:24:29Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2017-09-06T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2017-09-12T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20170914-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at very high levels during this reporting period with fifteen M-class flares and four X-class flares (see list below).  There were two C-type, one R-type and two O-type CMEs (see details below).   

Geomagnetic activity was at severe levels with a Kp index of (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=8 for the reporting period.  The highest period of Kp=8 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2017-09-07T21:00Z to 2017-09-08T00:00Z, 2017-09-08T00:00Z to 2017-09-08T03:00Z and 2017-09-08T12:00Z to 2017-09-08T15:00Z.  This severe geomagnetic storm was associated with the CME starting on 2017-09-06T12:24Z (associated with the X9.3-class flare; see notifications 20170906-AL-003, 20170906-AL-004, 20170906-AL-005, 20170906-AL-006, 20170907-AL-002 and 201709907-AL008). The CME arrival at L1 was detected by DSCOVR and ACE at around 2017-09-07T22:30Z (see notification  20170908-AL-003).  Simulations carried out at NASA GSFC CCMC/SWRC indicated that the magnetopause separating magnetospheric and solar wind plasma was close to the geosynchronous orbit starting at 2017-09-07T23:58Z (see notification 20170908-AL-001 and 20170908-AL-004). 

Two other CME arrivals were detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 during the reporting period.  The CMEs that started on 2017-09-04T19:39Z and  2017-09-04T20:36Z arrived at around 2017-09-06T23:08Z (see notification 20170907-AL-001) and the CME that started on 2017-09-10T16:09Z arrived (glancing blow) around 2017-09-12T19:26Z.  Neither of these CMEs caused a geomagnetic disturbance but they were associated with solar energetic particle events described below. 

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 10^5 pfu starting at 2017-09-09T07:10Z.  These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES 13 were associated with extended periods of high solar wind speed after the CME arrival detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 on 2017-09-07T22:30Z (see notifications 20170909-AL-001 and 20170909-AL-002).  

The > 10 MeV protons flux was already above threshold at the start of the reporting period, due to the solar energetic particle event on 2017-09-04 (see weekly report 20170906-7D-001).  Starting at 2017-09-06T23:45Z the flux of > 10 MeV protons exceeded 100 pfu. Also, the flux of one or more of the >15.8 MeV protons channels detected by SOHO exceeded 10^(-1) pfu/MeV starting at 2017-09-06T23:30Z. This enhancement is associated with the CME and X9.3 flare on 2017-09-06 (see notifications 20170906-AL-003, 20170906-AL-004, 20170906-AL-005, 20170906-AL-006, 20170907-AL-002 and 20170907-AL-008).  

Another solar energetic particle event was detected by GOES 13 on 2017-09-10.  The flux of > 10 MeV protons exceeded 10 pfu starting at 2017-09-10T16:45Z and the flux of > 100 MeV protons exceeded 1 pfu starting at 2017-09-10T16:25Z (see notifications 20170910-AL-002, 20170910-005).  The flux of one or more of the >15.8 MeV protons channels detected by SOHO exceeded 10^(-1) pfu/MeV starting at 2017-09-10T20:00Z (see notification 20170910-AL-008 and 20170912-002).  The energetic proton flux of 13-100 MeV protons detected at STEREO A was at background levels for the entire reporting period, but became slightly elevated (but below threshold) on 2017-09-11.  This solar energetic particle event was associated with the X8.2 flare and its associated CME that started on 2017-09-10T16:09Z. Several neutron monitor stations have detected this solar energetic particle event as a Ground Level Enhancement (GLE).

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been high this week due to the solar energetic particle event and the increased energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2017-09-13T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2017-09-19T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low to moderate for the next upcoming week.  Active region 2673 has already rotated behind the west limb but can still produce some far sided activity.  The active region 12680 (currently located on N06E34) is currently producing some solar flares and coronal mass ejections.   Geomagnetic activity is expected to be moderate for the upcoming week due to the expected arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2017-09-13 and 2017-09-14.  The flux of 13-100 MeV protons detected at STEREO A exceeded 10^(-1) pfu/MeV starting at 2017-09-13T05:33Z (after a data gap) (see notifications 20170913-AL-001 and 20170913-AL-002).  This is associated with the X8.2-class flare and its associated CME.

SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME update (ensemble) (STEREO B, Mars, Missions Near Earth)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-09-11T16:28:15Z
## Message ID: 20170911-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Ensemble modeling update on CME with ID 2017-09-10T16:09:00-CME-001 (see previous notifications 20170910-AL-006, 20170910-AL-007, 20170911-AL-001). Based on heliospheric ensemble modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact STEREO B and Mars. For 40 ensemble members (see notes section), simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach:

- STEREO B between about 2017-09-11T15:12Z and 2017-09-12T04:35Z (average arrival 2017-09-11T21:31Z) for 100% of simulations.
- Mars between about 2017-09-13T02:02Z and 2017-09-13T22:08Z (average arrival 2017-09-13T11:18Z) for 30% of simulations.

Additionally the CME is estimated to reach NASA missions near Earth between about 2017-09-12T10:41Z and 2017-09-12T23:49Z (average arrival 2017-09-12T16:06Z) for 12% of simulations.  The ensemble-based forecast indicates that there is a 75% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 3-4 range (below minor).

## Notes:
Ensemble CME modeling at SWRC is performed by building sets of initial CME parameters and carrying out separate simulations for each set. This approach allows a mapping of initial CME parameter uncertainties into a statistical characterization of CME arrival times and impact at locations of interest.

Description of links: For each location, the first link shows the WSA-ENLIL+Cone model animation for the median CME input parameters, the second link shows the probabilistic distribution of predicted arrival times histogram, and the third link shows a stack plot of the WSA-ENLIL+Cone modeled magnetic field, velocity, density, and temperature for all ensemble members. For missions near Earth, a histogram of the probabilistic Kp forecast is also provided.

For the full details of the modeled event, please go here:
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2017-09-10_ncmes1_sims40_HILOX065/Detailed_results_20170910_160900_ncmes1_sims40_HILOX065.txt

## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CMEs (Dawn, STEREO B, Mars, OSIRIS-REx, Missions Near Earth)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-09-11T16:22:21Z
## Message ID: 20170911-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Update on CME with ID 2017-09-10T16:09:00-CME-001. Updated CME parameters are (event upgraded R-type):

Start time of the event: 2017-09-10T16:09Z.

Estimated speed: ~2650 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 54 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 85/-12 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2017-09-10T16:09:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that the CME may affect Dawn, STEREO B, and Mars (glancing blow).  The leading edge of the CME will reach Dawn at 2017-09-14T20:52Z, STEREO B at 2017-09-11T20:09Z, and the flank will reach Mars at 2017-09-13T22:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 
  
The simulation also indicates that the CME may have a minor glancing blow at NASA missions near Earth with below minor geomagnetic effects. Simulations indicate that the flank of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2017-09-13T02:00Z (plus minus 7 hours) and OSIRIS-REx at about 2017-09-13T04:00Z (plus minus 7 hours).
   
Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME(s): 2017-09-09T16:48:00-CME-001, 2017-09-09T23:12:00-CME-001, 2017-09-10T16:09:00-CME-001):

## Notes: 

This CME event (2017-09-10T16:09:00-CME-001) is associated with the X8.2 flare with ID 2017-09-10T15:35:00-FLR-001 which peaked at 2017-09-10T16:06Z (see notification(s) 20170910-AL-001, 20170910-AL-003), SEP (>100 MeV) at GOES13 with ID 2017-09-10T16:25:00-SEP-001 (see notification(s) 20170910-AL-002), SEP (>10 MeV) at GOES13 with ID 2017-09-10T16:45:00-SEP-001 (see notification(s) 20170910-AL-004, 20170910-AL-005), and SEP at SOHO with ID 2017-09-10T20:00:00-SEP-001 (see notification(s) 20170910-AL-008). There has been a slight increase in teh 13-100 MeV proton flux at STEREO A but it is well below the threshold of 10^(-1) pfu/MeV. Several neutron monitor stations have detected a Ground Level Enhancement (GLE) associated with this activity.

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux is above 10^5 pfu starting at 2017-09-09T07:10Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Ongoing space weather storm in the Earth's magnetosphere. Geomagnetic Kp index has reached level 8 (severe) during the synoptic period 2017-09-08T12:00Z to 2017-09-08T15:00Z.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME update (ensemble) (Missions Near Earth)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-09-07T18:10:48Z
## Message ID: 20170907-AL-008
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

BETA PRODUCT. ENSEMBLE PRODUCT IS STILL IN DEVELOPMENT MODE. PLEASE LET US KNOW IF YOU HAVE ANY SUGGESTIONS FOR MODIFICATIONS.  

Ensemble modeling update on the CME with the ID 2017-09-06T12:24:00-CME-001 (see previous notifications 20170907-AL-002 and 20170906-AL-006).

Based on heliospheric ensemble modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact NASA missions near Earth. Out of 40 ensemble members (see notes section), 40 (100%) indicate impact at NASA missions near Earth. Ensemble simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth between about 2017-09-08T06:58Z and 2017-09-09T02:02Z (average arrival 2017-09-08T15:48Z). The ensemble-based forecast indicates that there is a 87% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 4-6 range (below minor to moderate).

Links to the ensemble details of the modeled event:
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2017-09-07_ncmes1_sims40_HILOX064/20170906_122400_ncmes1_sims40_HILOX064_anim_tim-den.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2017-09-07_ncmes1_sims40_HILOX064/20170906_122400_ncmes1_sims40_HILOX064_arrival_Earth.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2017-09-07_ncmes1_sims40_HILOX064/20170906_122400_ncmes1_sims40_HILOX064_Earth_stack.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2017-09-07_ncmes1_sims40_HILOX064/20170906_122400_ncmes1_sims40_HILOX064_probabilistic_Kp_forecast_wdist.gif

## Notes:
Ensemble CME modeling at SWRC is performed by building sets of initial CME parameters and carrying out separate simulations for each set. This approach allows a mapping of initial CME parameter uncertainties into a statistical characterization of CME arrival times and impact at locations of interest.

Description of links: For each location, the first link shows the WSA-ENLIL+Cone model animation for the median CME input parameters, the second link shows the probabilistic distribution of predicted arrival times histogram, and the third link shows a stack plot of the WSA-ENLIL+Cone modeled magnetic field, velocity, density, and temperature for all ensemble members. For missions near Earth, a histogram of the probabilistic Kp forecast is also provided.

For the full details of the modeled event, please go here:
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2017-09-07_ncmes1_sims40_HILOX064/Detailed_results_20170906_122400_ncmes1_sims40_HILOX064.txt

## Summary:

Ongoing solar energetic particle event detected by GOES.  The flux of > 10 MeV protons exceeds 100 pfu starting at 2017-09-06T23:45Z. This is largely due to the interplanetary shock (2017-09-06T23:08:00-IPS-001 (see notification(s) 20170907-AL-001) from the 2017-09-04 CMEs. In addition, the recent X9.3 flare (2017-09-06T11:54:00-FLR-001) and its associated CME (Activity ID: 2017-09-06T12:24:00-CME-001) also contributed to the enhancement.

NASA spacecraft at MEO, GEO and other high-altitude orbits and high-inclination LEO can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2017-09-06T23:45:00-SEP-001.

## Notes:

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for August 30, 2017 - September 05, 2017
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-09-06T20:21:28Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2017-08-30T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2017-09-05T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20170906-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at very high levels during this reporting period with 12 M-class flares (see list below) from active region 12673. There were 2 C-type CMEs and 1 O-type CME (see details below).   
Based on heliospheric ensemble modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that the CMEs starting at 2017-09-04T19:39Z and  2017-09-04T20:36Z may impact NASA missions near Earth and OSIRIS-REx  (see notifications 20170905-AL-003, 20170905-AL-004 and 20170905-AL-005). Out of 40 ensemble members (see notes section), 40 (100%) indicate impact at NASA missions near Earth and OSIRIS-REx between about 2017-09-07T00:58Z and 2017-09-07T23:09Z (average arrival 2017-09-07T09:02Z). The ensemble-based forecast indicates that there is a 89% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 4-7 range (below minor to moderate).  The CME starting at 2017-09-04T20:36Z is associated with the M5.5 flare that peaked at 2017-09-04T20:33Z (see notifications 20170904-AL-001 and 20170904-AL-002).

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=5 was reached during the synoptic periods of 2017-08-31T06:00Z - 2017-08-31T15:00Z, 2017-09-02T03:00Z - 2017-09-02T09:00Z and 2017-09-04T21:00Z - 2017-09-05T00:00Z.  The slight elevation on 2017-08-31 was associated with a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2017-08-31. Simulations carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center indicated that the high speed stream arrival also caused that the magnetopause boundary separating magnetospheric and solar wind plasma was close to the geosynchronous orbit around 2017-08-31T06:56Z (see notifications 20170831-AL-001 and 20170831-AL-002).  The minor activity on 2017-09-04 was associated to another coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2017-09-04.  The solar wind speed reached values of >650 km/s and >600 km/s, respectively for each high speed stream. 
 
The 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 10^5 pfu starting at 2017-09-03T15:25Z. These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES 13 were associated with the coronal hole high speed stream arrival described above on 2017-08-31 (see notifications 20170903-AL-001 and 20170903-AL-002).  

The flux of > 10 MeV protons exceeded 10 pfu starting at 2017-09-05T00:30Z.  This solar energetic particle event detected by GOES was associated with the M5.5 class flare that peaked at 2017-09-04T20:33Z and the CMEs starting at 2017-09-04T19:39Z and 2017-09-04T20:36Z (see notifications 20170905-AL-001 and 20170905-AL-002).  Also, the flux of one or more of the >15.8 MeV protons channels at SOHO exceeded 10^(-1) pfu/MeV starting at 2017-09-04T23:52Z.

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been high this week due to the solar energetic particle event and the increased energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2017-09-06T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2017-09-12T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be moderate to high for the upcoming week. Active region 12673 continues to produce solar flares and CMEs. On 2017-09-06 it has produced 3 M-class flares and 2 X-class flares (X2.2 and X9.3) (see notifications 20170906-AL-001, 20170906-AL-002, 20170906-AL-003, and 20170906-AL-004).  The X9.3 flare peaked around  2017-09-06T12:02Z and has an associated CME that started around 2017-09-06T12:24Z and was estimated to be traveling at a speed of ~1800 km/s.  Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that this CME may impact NASA missions near Earth and OSIRIS-REx at about 2017-09-08T18:27Z (plus or minus 7 hours) (see notifications 20170906-AL-005 and 20170906-AL-006).  Also, several additional active regions as present on both the Earth-facing side of the solar disk and in the STEREO A view. Geomagnetic activity is expected to be moderate to high due to the expected arrival of the combined CMEs that started on 2017-09-04T19:39Z, 2017-09-04T20:36Z, and 2017-09-06T12:24Z.  Strong geomagnetic conditions are expected.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CMEs update (ensemble) (Missions Near Earth)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-09-05T20:27:45Z
## Message ID: 20170905-AL-005
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

BETA PRODUCT. ENSEMBLE PRODUCT IS STILL IN DEVELOPMENT MODE. PLEASE LET US KNOW IF YOU HAVE ANY SUGGESTIONS FOR MODIFICATIONS.  

Ensemble modeling update on CME(s) with ID(s) 2017-09-04T20:36:00-CME-001 and 2017-09-04T19:39:00-CME-001 (see previous notification 20170905-AL-004). 

Based on heliospheric ensemble modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that the CMEs may impact NASA missions near Earth. Out of 40 ensemble members (see notes section), 40 (100%) indicate impact at NASA missions near Earth. Ensemble simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CMEs will reach NASA missions near Earth between about 2017-09-07T00:58Z and 2017-09-07T23:09Z (average arrival 2017-09-07T09:02Z). The ensemble-based forecast indicates that there is a 89% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 4-7 range (below minor to moderate).

Links to the ensemble details of the modeled event:
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2017-09-05_ncmes2_sims40_HILOX063/20170904_203600_ncmes2_sims40_HILOX063_anim_tim-den.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2017-09-05_ncmes2_sims40_HILOX063/20170904_203600_ncmes2_sims40_HILOX063_arrival_Earth.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2017-09-05_ncmes2_sims40_HILOX063/20170904_203600_ncmes2_sims40_HILOX063_Earth_stack.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2017-09-05_ncmes2_sims40_HILOX063/20170904_203600_ncmes2_sims40_HILOX063_probabilistic_Kp_forecast_wdist.gif

## Notes:
Ensemble CME modeling at SWRC is performed by building sets of initial CME parameters and carrying out separate simulations for each set. This approach allows a mapping of initial CME parameter uncertainties into a statistical characterization of CME arrival times and impact at locations of interest.

Description of links: For each location, the first link shows the WSA-ENLIL+Cone model animation for the median CME input parameters, the second link shows the probabilistic distribution of predicted arrival times histogram, and the third link shows a stack plot of the WSA-ENLIL+Cone modeled magnetic field, velocity, density, and temperature for all ensemble members. For missions near Earth, a histogram of the probabilistic Kp forecast is also provided.

For the full details of the modeled event, please go here:
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2017-09-05_ncmes2_sims40_HILOX063/Detailed_results_20170904_203600_ncmes2_sims40_HILOX063.txt

## Summary:

Multiple CMEs have been detected as follows:
1: O-type CME detected by SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2017-09-04T20:36Z.
(Please note:  This simulation is an update to include both CMEs that were observed late on 2017-09-04. 
The 2017-09-04T20:36Z CME was previously denoted as 2017-09-04T21:00:00-CME-001 in Notification 20170905-AL-003, with a start time based on the earliest available image in the LASCO data of the CME.  Updated LASCO data showed an earlier start time, and this CME now has Activity ID 2017-09-04T20:36:00-CME-001.)

Estimated speed: ~1114 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 46 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 10/-10 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2017-09-04T20:36:00-CME-001

2: C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2017-09-04T19:39Z.

Estimated speed: ~710 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 25 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 26/-6 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2017-09-04T19:39:00-CME-001

 
Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that the CMEs may impact NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CMEs will reach NASA missions near Earth and OSIRIS-REx at about 2017-09-07T03:45Z (plus or minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 4-6 (below minor to moderate).

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - SEP
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-09-05T00:55:18Z
## Message ID: 20170905-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar energetic particle event detected by GOES.  The flux of > 10 MeV protons exceeds 10 pfu starting at 2017-09-05T00:30Z.

NASA spacecraft at MEO, GEO and other high-altitude orbits and high-inclination LEO can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2017-09-05T00:30:00-SEP-001.

## Notes: 

This SEP event (2017-09-05T00:30:00-SEP-001) is associated with M5.5 flare with ID 2017-09-04T20:15:00-FLR-001 which peaked at 2017-09-04T20:33Z (see notification(s) 20170904-AL-001, 20170904-AL-002).  An associated CME has also been detected in two SOHO LASCO images with a plane-of-sky speed of approximately 1000-1500 km/s. Updates will be provided when available.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-09-03T15:51:37Z
## Message ID: 20170903-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux is above 10^5 pfu starting at 2017-09-03T15:25Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by the high speed stream starting at 2017-08-31T04:40Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2017-09-03T15:25:00-RBE-001.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Magnetopause Crossing
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-08-31T11:46:47Z
## Message ID: 20170831-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Strong compression of the magnetosphere possibly detected. Simulations carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center indicate that the magnetopause separating magnetospheric and solar wind plasma is close to the geosynchronous orbit starting at 2017-08-31T06:56Z.

The activity is associated with the high speed stream starting at 2017-08-31.

NASA spacecraft at the geosynchronous orbits may be exposed to solar wind plasma and magnetic field conditions.

Activity ID: 2017-08-31T06:56:00-MPC-001.
